However, there were only three tiny little tables in the restaurant that felt claustrophobic considering the number of people lined up close by purchasing pastries. We decided to abandon our original dine-in plan and just went home with take-out. The lack of space and inability to enjoy dining in the shop is the reason this bakery gets 4 stars instead of 5.

The items that were purchased were out-of-this-world ridiculously delicious! We tried the following:
Pain au chocolat ou Chocolatine (Chocolate Croissant)
Quiche Vegetarienne (Goat Cheese and Spinach Quiche)
Délice de Pistache (Pastry filled with Pistachio Mousse and Chocolate Chips)
Eclairs au chocolat  (Chocolate Eclair)
Marquise (Creme Brulee, Caramel, and Chocolate Mousse wrapped in a Chocolate shell)

My husband I snacked on these tasty treats all day Saturday and Sunday. Mmmm mmm mmm. I will definitely be back soon!

The display actually wasn't that appealing. Flattened croissants. Some of the chocolate cakes lost their oomph. 
I got a chocolate almond croissant, my favorite, and it was crunchy. Like day olds. But it wasn't even noon yet. I was sad. This place was so highly recommended.

I admit, I'm a Jean Marc's loyalist. When I have a hankering for some delicious French pastries, I hightail it to Millvale to get my fill of buttery deliciousness. Unfortunately for me, Jean Marc isn't always around when my pastry cravings strike (how dare he close his shop on Sundays!), and I need to fill that void. 

La Gourmandine definitely holds its own when it comes to the French pastry game. I've been here several times now and have always been fairly happy with my selections. I've never tried their desserts, but as far as breakfast pastries go, theirs are solid. The croissants are quite delicious -- buttery, flaky, and chewy like a good croissant should be. Occasionally I find that they are *slightly* more crispy and overdone on the top than I'd prefer, but it's not a huge deal. Their La Gourmandise breakfast pastry is probably my favorite...puff pastry filled with a not-very-sweet vanilla pastry cream and chocolate chips. So flaky and tons of flavor in each bite...it's divine. I'm not a fan of their signature almond croissant that everyone else seems to love...it's too syrupy sweet for my taste and I'm not a fan of the crumbly texture. 

Overall, although I do prefer Jean Marc's, if you're looking for authentic and delicious French pastries, you won't go wrong with La Gourmandine

The best french bakery hands down.  I live in Virginia and wish there was something close to the level of greatness as this place.  Every time I come up to Pittsburgh,  I make sure to stop here for their tuna and turkey sandwiches.  The french bread is to die for and it is the best I have every tasted.  If you are in town check this place out!

I was instructed to get the almond croissant on my first visit here.  Unfortunately, not a single almond croissant was to be found.  Instead, a very helpful employee explained what my other options were and offered her suggestions.  I had a wonderful apple tart that was a combination of spiced apples and applesauce.

I also bought a baguette, which I heard they are famous for.  I couldn't even make it home without trying a piece (or three).  It was really delicious.  The location is a bit out of the way, but Butler and Lawrenceville are expanding, and I'm excited to see what else is coming!

Butter butter everywhere!! I selected six pastry in lieu of a traditional bakery cake for a birthday celebration. All were terrific. "Must try-s" are the Paris Brest and the almond croissant. Choux à la Crème and the Chocolate cakes -- either hazelnut or yellow cake -- were heavenly. Avoid the simple vanilla custard -- while  it is good, it is not as outstanding as most other goodies.
Just another great place in Pittsburgh ! French bakery is really good everything was fresh! Coffee was good! Really enjoyed it all

We were referred to this shop courtesy of another local shopkeeper who mentioned the owner was from France and produces consistent quality bread and pastry.  Visiting the shop took my wife and I back to a small pastry shop we once stumbled upon while walking the streets of Montmartre.  Pastry we tried we outstanding.  We both agreed that any future trips to Pittsburgh would require a return visit to this shop.

I can't remember the name of the pastry I got. But it was so good! When I ordered it I originally thought it was a giant cookie, though that is not the best way to describe it. Very light, not too sweet. Fruit-jam-type filling and powdered sugar. Generous sizing. We went in on a cold day near Christmas and only had to wait a minute or so before we were served. 

There is no seating, only a standing table if I remember correctly. Anyway. This place is great for a treat! That's what we went in for, and it exceeded my expectations.
Excellent. Stopped here during a road trip from DC, found the pastries and sandwiches to be delightful and the staff welcoming and friendly. Wouldn't miss this place on return trips.

OOOOOORRRRRLLLLLHHHHHHHHH GAAAWWDDDDD. That's really the best way to describe what you will say if you eat one of their creations. Highly recommend the chocolate eclairs and the almond croissant. And even better, the cashiers are ALWAYS super friendly and have a smile on their face.

Don't count on dining in here, because it is small with limited seating.

The almond croissant I had was absolutely perfect decadence. I can't wait to go back.

I saw this place has 5 full stars and I just had to---pop the bubble.  Mainly because it's really not all that great.  Have you all tried Jean Marc in Millvale?  This place cannot hold a French candlelight  to Jean Marc!  

Cons: It's more expensive, the chocolate croissants have less chocolate, and the signature almond croissant was ho-hum to me. 

Pros: This place does have a very nice location and it does look very pretty inside and out.  It has a couple tables to sit at.  It has a wider variety as it is a bakery (I was eyeing one of those French sandwiches).

Main point is I would come back only if all the bridges to Millvale were blocked and if that were the case, I might just give up my French bakery excursion altogether.  

Try Jean Marc!

I love this place! A friend told me about it so we decided to head over before we hit the strip for some shopping. We parked around 8:40am (opens at 9am) on a Saturday and there was already a line by the door! I saw a bunch of runners in line and I thought it was funny how they went for their morning run and then got in line for some baked goodies. Sounds legit. It made me even more curious about this place and their sweets.

As soon as it hit 9am, the door opened and the intense smell of heaven came wafting out. Everyone formed a nice line and filed in with order. I got a Eclairs au chocolat and some coffee. The staff there was quick to respond to requests so the line came in and out quickly. I liked that even though I really wanted to kneel down and gawk at all the stuff I still wanted to try while I took mental pictures of everything in the case before it was my turn to get my butt out so someone else could drool. Coming back ASAP!
Delicious croissants and bread. It smells like heaven in this place. They also have sandwiches you can order but I have not tried them yet. If you're in the area definitely don't miss out!

I'm not really sure it gets any better than La Gourmandine. Sure, there's no sense to the layout of the bakery, the lines can get long, and they'll offer seasonal items that blow your mind for a few weeks only to never return again (ex. religieux au caramel)...but it's worth the "hard times" to visit and load up on the sweet goodness that fills up this small French bakery.

The sweets are incredible. Macarons, tarts, eclairs, etc. I've tried every single item in the displays case at least once...and for the most part, I've rarely met a dessert on this level that can match La Gourmandine at other bakeries. From savory, to sour, to sweet, they nail all of the flavor profiles. They have a dessert for everyone. Rich, decadent options and more savory ones. One of my favorites on the sweet side is the macaron au fruit. It's a giant macaron with raspberries and cream in the middle. Talk about the perfect variety of textures and an overload of flavor! I could go on all day about their desserts...so amazing.

If you don't have a sweet tooth, not to worry. They have excellent baguettees, sandwiches (albeit only three varieties), quiches, and things like the tarte aux brie. I seriously can't say that I've ever had anything bad from the place. Sure, I haven't loved everything, but that came down to me not being a fan of hazelnut (gasps from the masses of nutella fans), more than the Paris-brest being at fault. Ha. 

Overall, you can't go wrong at La Gourmandine. Great food, desserts, and smells paired with super-nice employees and reasonable prices. Also, it's fun to chat with the other people in line for a sense of community in the mornings. What's not to love!

Lunch in Lawrenceville? Make it La Gourmandine.  Love the pastries and the sandwiches.  My favorite was the prosciutto with the baby pickles, but honestly I don't think you can go wrong with any of them.  Their baguettes are crispy on the outside but soft on the inside and make wonderful sandwiches.

I've been trying to not indulge my sweet tooth too much recently, so I've skipped the fantastic looking pastries most times.  I did give in a couple times though.  Once was a double chocolate mousse, and the other was a fruit tart   Both were good, but the chocolate mousse was amazing.

This place is one of my favorite bakeries I've ever been to.

The food is great quality, crafted with care and the environment has an authentic French vibe to it. The service is always fast and friendly, although they can get a little swamped on the weekends.

I love the Cheux La Creme and Chocolate Croissants, but also the Tomato Soup I had was really awesome. I would stop here every morning if I could and didn't mind packing on 100 extra lbs.

La Gourmandine was high on my list. I was determined and I ended up expending much effort in the behalf of my visit. I had to run here (literally), my belly full of pork schnitzel (not joking), blood spewing from my nose (again, I don't lie much), just to quickly snatch an Almond Croissant before they closed. Was it worth it? Is that even a question? 

For me the only obvious comparison was Gaby et Jules, since I haven't been to Jean-Marc yet. They differ greatly. If Gaby is a piece of marble, then Gourmi is a brick. Not a bad thing, just way different, less polished. With comfort food instead of edible art (albeit art that is incredibly fine-tasting). La Gourmandine is soft and calm and specializes in similarly designed bread based pastries. So I don't know what else and how else to say other than this: the Almond Croissant is absolutely stunning. It was a thing of dreams. Dreams that take place in the hearts of Frenchmen and Lawrencevillians alike. 

Buuut, (here it comes; it wasn't quite perfect) the La Gourmandine people seemed slightly grumpy, especially when compared to the shine-your-shoes-just-for-buying-a-macaron grade of service at Gaby et Jules. And speaking of which, La Gourmandine's were far from perfect. Too crunchy and sugary; better stick with the the croissants. So I still like Gaby a bit better. (I'm sorry, ok!) Really, Gaby and Gourmi together is less of a comparison and more of a conclusion. Between the two, they have everything you might ever want. All ye Pittsburghers have no excuse to not be so happy.

I stopped by to ogle the fresh pastries and purchased a cream puff that was a treat for my husband and I. I also purchased a tuna sandwich for lunch that was absolutely heavenly. I saw a couple enjoying a cappuccino and croissant and I was seriously jealous. I need to go back and try the chocolate croissant!!

This place is AH-mazing! I live just a few blocks away so I have to reign it in with the amount of trips we make there. I haven't had bread this good since I lived in Paris! Their veggie sandwiches are really great, too! The only thing I'm not super keen on is the macaroons- there's a place in Market Sq. I prefer to get them from, but other than that, this place literally cannot.be.beat!!!

Decent food, horrible service, specifically from the manger. I came with a friend, he ordered a sandwich, I ordered a quiche, to eat in. They gave me utensils. I took one bite of the quiche, it was cold. Obviously it's meant to be eaten warm. I went right back and asked the cashier if he could heat it for me. He was very nice and took it and was about to do it, when the manager, not even looking at me, asked him (right there in front of me): did she eat from it? I said: I took a bite and found it cold. She told him (again i'm standing right there), you can't heat it. Poor guy was just standing awkwardly not knowing what to do. She said it's a health hazard (contamination). Now I'm all for avoiding cross-contamination. I told her I never put the fork back in the pie. I literally took the bite off my fork and came right back to get it heated. How is putting a pie in the microwave or whatever they heat it in going to contaminate everything. She would not even look at me actually and was being extremely disrespectful. The cashier was still holding the pie and not knowing what to do. There was a line of people and I was getting choked up because I was actually shocked that this was happening. I finally took the quiche from the guy and left. Never came back. That was about a year ago. I still felt compelled to write this review because I drive by this place every day on the way home and never want to go back in. The food is not worth being treated poorly.

I've been to Paris a handful of times. I lived there for a summer when I was 17. Never, have I had French pastries, croissants, or bread as good outside of the city of lights. 

My fiancee and I went there this morning for the first time and were blown away. We ordered a quiche, a loaf of rye bread, a butter croissant, a pain au chocolat (chocolate croissant), and  a pain au raisin, (a pastry with raisins...my favorite). Each was delicious. The quiche was light and fluffy (like it should be). The croissants were filled with enough butter to make them melt in your mouth. And the bread (which we tried at home) was crunchy on the outside, soft on the inside, and delicious all around.

I can't express how excited I am that we now have an authentic and outstanding French bakery in Pittsburgh. If only it were in Squirrel HIll (where I live) and not in Lawrenceville. I guess we'll have to make more trips out that way!

A friend and I went on a sunny Saturday morning, and the line stretched outside the store and extended past the next store. While waiting I secretly hated all the customers coming out with their pretty white boxes full of pastries. 
The worst part was when I was forced to wait in the door of the bakery, the sweet buttery smells wafted through the air and caresses my nostrils. 
I couldn't help myself but spend an exorbitant amount of money (I'm sure you will too). Money was the only thing getting in the way of me and every patisserie there. 
I got the delice de pistache, croissant, pain de chocolat, and and almond croissant. Needless to say I ate them all in one sitting. The croissant was perfectly flaky on the outside and sickly doughy on the inside. Everything was gone in less than 5 minutes, leaving me with an empty box, and an array of smeared napkins strewn around my feet.  
I stared longingly at the bakery, regretting the fact that I didn't get more...

TLDR: get everything or you will regret it.

The best bakery I've ever been to! Highly
Recommend the Almond Croissant, Ham & Cheese croissant (have them warm it up!) and any of the Tarts!
Came by for breakfast and grabbed an almond croissant. It was amazing. I'm pretty sure I've never had a better croissant in my life.

The decor is great, everything is laid out very cleanly so you can easily see their pastries, breads and desserts. I went back recently, and they removed their seating, which I liked but I understand that space can be quite tight when they're busy.

I feel that their highlights are their pastries. Croissants are phenomenal, anything with butter and sugar is baked perfectly. Sweets are elegantly put together and actually very sweet. Perhaps you should take an insulin syringe with you just in case you get too large of a sugar spike... (just kidding) but seriously they're very good.

What i didn't like was their baguette. I bought baguettes on separate occasions and both were overly salted and a bit dense. I was really hoping for something with a more open crumb. Perhaps both days I went were off days, but I usually go for their pastries and sweets, and occasionally to bask in the pretentiousness of a bakery that wants to be known as French.

hands down. one of the best places in pittsburgh. i love this place so much. i have tried to find other amazing french pastry shops in other cities. the only place i have found one that compares to the caliber of La Gourmandine is in NYC, all else fail the test. 
these folks totally spoil pittsburgh and i am so grateful!!!!
The best croissants in Pittsburgh.  The coffee was good too!

I'm so unbelievably sad that they stopped making kouign aman, but I guess I can forgive them because the la gourmandise and the tuna baguettes are so good. 
The tuna baguette is just simple tuna salad with cucumber, tomato, red onion, and mayo on a perfectly crunchy/chewy baguette. A simple lunch that would have a difficult time being more delicious.
They do have a cocktail table where you can stand and eat your pastry or sandwich, or you can go to the park across the street and enjoy some of the rare pittsburgh sunshine. Or, if your like me, you can drag your preggers self to your car and devour the entire baguette while other drivers stare at you. I promise not to judge!

This is the best bakery in Pittsburgh. Nothing to add that other reviewers haven't mentioned already: The croissants are very, very good (particularly the croissant auxes almande), the tarte au citron is almost perfect with the beautiful lemon acidity balanced with the sweet richness of the shell, the mini tarte tatins and tarte au poire are fantastic, and the mille feuille and opera pastries are decadent without being cloying. The only thing I can think of to improve is to add an espresso counter (apologies if I missed it). Highly recommended!

This place is beautiful and delicious... plus, the people who work there are very nice! It's an overwhelming place to walk into... you're smacked in the face by dozens of pieces of edible art and it's hard to decide which to get. Many people agree with me so be prepared for lines at peak times (like weekend mornings). The coffee is okay, though... just okay. But that's not why you're there!

This bakery and pastry shop is consistently delightful in every way!!   It's such a wonderful addition to Pittsburgh's culinary choices!! I frequently go well out of my way to indulge in their delectable selections. I lament the fact that they are rather far off the path of my regular travels. This may be a blessing, however, as I would otherwise fear for my waistline!  For sweet treats to savory eats, you don't want to miss this place! And no matter what else seduces your palate, add a few butter croissants to your order - they're by far some of the best I've had outside of France. Bon appétit!!

Dear delightful french bakery next door. Your hours suck. And you need to stop playing coy and open on Sunday. I mean seriously? Tuesday can eff off. I need a pastry and some delicious coffee on Sunday morning. Also, I love your baguettes and sandwiches. This is one of those places that will bring joy to your heart. (Assuming your heart is also closed on Sunday)

What's not to love about a little French bakery with macarons?! A friend and I stopped here after some shopping at No. 14 boutique right up the street. The sales associates recommended it and said there is always a line out the door. We showed up and as she said there was a like out the door. But no worries it moves very quickly! Due to the fact I just had brunch I opted to only get 3 of their macarons and 1 of their larger macarons. They were all gone within minutes. The large macaron I got was a raspberry macaron with cream and raspberries layered on the inside. It was by far the best macaron I have had. They also had a lot of sandwiches and pastries that looked heavenly that I would like to go back and try one of these days.
Go! This place will make you feel like Amelie. The owners are friendly, the prices are reasonable, and the pastries will make you wet.

Can't top all that's already been written about this place, so I'm just going to say. Yes. Go here. Why? Nice people. Delicious pastries. What more do you need? 

I'd be 200 pounds if this was in my neighborhood because I would put hundreds of those chouquettes into my face every day. Thank you!

This bakery offers really authentic French pastries!! 
Although the desserts were not mindblowing, they were very decadent and very well prepared.
We went there and spent $25 to get a sample of everything: pastries (the plain croissants, pain au chocolat and the chocolate and eggs braid -- don't recall its french name), desserts (lemon tartelette, a chocolate semi-froid with ganache on top and a raspberry bavaroise) and the bread. Out of all these, i truly recommend the plain croissants, the chocolate braids and the lemon tartelette: they were really really good! finally, one place in pittsburgh made me feel we don't need to miss europe for pastries. :)

SETTING:
Cute little french pastry shop with a clean and cozy interior. A handful of tables (about four) that seat two people each. Not a very big place, so probably best to get things to go or come during off hours if you want to eat here. I heard lines can get pretty long which would crowd the bakery quickly.

PASTRIES:
I think they only make a certain amount each day, so once they're sold out (which happens) then you're out of luck. To me, this speaks to the quality and freshness.

Got me the Almond Croissant that was recommended by a friend. Excuse me while I wipe the white powder that is sugary goodness off my lips. 

Personally, I don't like things that are super sweet (ie: I dilute my fruit juices with water to cut down on the sugar...don't judge me!). This pastry was just about right on the sweet-o-meter. A tad bit on the sweet side though, so I cut it in half to save for later. I don't think I would be able to finish the whole thing in one sitting without feeling guilty or bouncing off the walls from the sugar high. My friends who got the almond croissant all raved about it, and I agree. No doubt, it was delicious. Parts of the base/bottom tasted a bit doughy though, but it wasn't a big deal...maybe that's how its supposed to be? I'd definitely get the croissant again and try the other pastries.

SERVICE:
Very polite, warm, and patient people working in the shop. Gave some good recommendations about their offerings. Classy establishment with classy people. 

IMPRESSIONS:
I'd love to come back and try the other pastries! Reasonably priced and delicately made. If you ever want to "treat yoself," stop by and check it out. I already feel a withdrawl coming on...uh oh. It would be dangerous if they delivered.
The girlfriend got me a flourless chocolate cake from here for my birthday and it was divine. Would highly recommend this place.

We stopped here a few times while we stayed in Pittsburgh.

Everything we tried was GOOD. We wanted to try more, but we ran out of time. Highly recommended!

I think the only downside is that it's kind of small. We stopped to grab a coffee and have a sandwich one morning and standing around at the tables isn't always fun.

The quality and authenticity of this bakery . . . Second to none in this city. Honestly, the value of these baked goods is incredible. I pride myself on being a connoisseur (ehmm, French) of the croissant. And this bakery's croissant . . . My goodness. It's like I've died and have gone back to . . . Cambodia (I've never been to France, but the Cambodians make some mean French pastries)? They have multiple varieties that are all delicious. Perfectly buttery. Perfectly flaky. Perfectly delicious. Oui!!! 

Get a croissant. 

Also, buy everything else in their nice display case. Everything is so visually appealing. These baked goods are like works of art. And the tastes perfectly match the quality of the appearances.

The shop itself is also very nice. It's very quaint. Very charming. Honestly, I was half expecting Meg Ryan and Tom Hanks to show up to split a piece of quiche. You walk in and have to honestly ask yourself, "Am . . . am I in France?" 

Yeah. You're not. But you might as well be. 

If you enjoy quality baked goods at great prices, stop at La Gourmandine. You won't be disappointed. Everything from the employees to the shop to the goods themselves is so, oh, so inviting.

I absolutely love La Gourmadine Bakery! I've been here several times, always on a Saturday morning. There is always a line of people waiting to get their favorites. Ive never been to any other locations. My favorites are the breakfast pastries including the abricotine and croissant aux amandes. I highly recommend both if you like breakfast pastries. The croissants are also deliciously flakey and buttery. Macaroons and torts are always amazing! I haven't had a thing I didn't like! 

The interior is small but with a few tables to sit at if you want to eat your goodies there! Staff has always been nice but I do feel a little rushed sometimes when there is a line and they are trying to move you along. I don't recommend getting in line until you know what you want!

Delicious.  

But don't go because I don't want you clogging up the store, creating a long line and possibly taking the last of my favorite pastry.
Yum! Tempting selection of breads, pastries, savory sandwiches, and more!  So glad we stopped here.

we had quiche lorraine and the quiche with spinach/goat cheese (my mother and i just ate lunch here today) - both were really delicious- portions were good and priced at $5 (including a drink) each was pretty good. no tables to sit and eat at inside...which was a bummer since i had my 9 month old with me and i was carrying him, but other than that it was great. there are 3 standing tables inside...no seating. i'd eat here again in a heartbeat (and i will!)

Dare I say this reminds me of an actual Parisian bakery? Minimal standing only high tables with just a few outdoor seats facing the street. The set up is definitely authentic, so right off the bat I have a good feeling about this. 

La Gourmandine offers traditional French pastries, baked goods, and a few savory items. Unfortunate there's only so much real estate my stomach can muster in one sitting, so I go with the quiche Lorraine, croissant au beurre(plain), and croissant almande(almond). 

Quiche Lorraine: I generally am not a fan of quiche(only because they would be 10 times better if served warm) but this is super tasty. Bacon, Caramelized onions, and eggs. What's not to love?!

Croissant au beurre: to be honest, I've never had a croissant stateside that tastes anything like an actual Parisian version, but this is pretty good 

Croissant almande: I chose to save the best for last. I actually fell in love with almond croissants at a Belgian restaurant in NYC. That was the best I ever had. After trying dozen all over, I found another excellent version in Ottawa, Ontario. A dozen or so terrible versions later, I stumble on la Gourmandine! Not the traditional croissant, as it basically looks like it's been flattened, but amazing nonetheless. The filling is not too sweet, the powdered sugar is not overkill, and the almonds are plentiful. Yes, all that matters. 

Oh and the staff themselves? Exceptional! Not only patient and helpful, but quite gracious. I ended up leaving the "to go" portion of my order in a bag on one of the outside tables. Not only did they hold it for me until I returned, but they without me asking, decided to give me new pastries just in case someone tampered with it. Now that's how you win a customer! 

Nowhere really feels like Paris but Paris itself; but in terms of bakeries, this is pretty darn close

Finally tried this bakery which has been on my list for quite some time during the Lawrenceville Cookie Tour.

I'm giving it 4 vs. 5 stars because with all the hype and praise, I thought it would have more selections.  It's a rather small bakery with a small selection.  Mind you, what they do have and what I tried was very good; I was just expecting more.

I had a chocolate éclair and some almond concoction.  Both were excellent.

Staff is friendly, helpful, and efficient so if there's a line; be patient.  It goes fast and is worth the wait.

I'm in love with this place. One thing I love about France is the plethora of pastry/bakery shops.  I was happy to learn about this place from my colleagues, and ever since my first visit, I've been trying to come here every weekend to get my fix for croissants and other pastries.

Food (10/10) = I haven't had anything I didn't like.  The croissants are my favorite item so far.  Buttery, flaky, fluffy pillows of tongue pleasure.  What more could you want, other than a hot cup of coffee to go with it?  Killer combo.  Other things I've enjoyed are Pain au chocolat ou Chocolatine, Pain de Campagne , and the Focaccia.  One of the things I enjoyed about France were the sandwiches.  Le Parisien and Le Montagnard bring back great memories.  And the Marquise...wtf? Dark chocolate mousse with crème brûlée and crispy caramel?  What genius came up with this innovation?

Ambiance (8/10) = beautiful presentation of the pastries.  Small, cozy feel with brick walls.  Wish there were more tables/seats.

Service (8/10) = good service.  standard. smiling.

Overall Opinion = What a gem.  Great place for baked goods period.  Always looking forward to my next visit to La Gourmandine.

I absolutely love this bakery.  On this trip I decided to try the chocolate eclair. It was a chocolate lovers delight filled with chocolate mousse and topped with chocolate icing. It was the perfect pairing with my cup of coffee.

Recently had wandered in to pick up some macarons. I did get there late in the day so very few were left (hence only 4 stars), but what they did have were giant (twice the size) raspberry and lychee macarons. They were cooked PEREFCTLY, had a great balance between the sweet lychee cream, raspberry cookie and fresh raspberries in the cream. Tremendously delicious. I highly recommend this French bakery, but suggest not waiting for the afternoon to roll around.

Came to Pittsburgh for a visit and a friend took us here. Wow, everything was amazing in this cute little shop. I ordered a French macroon sandwich (that's right) filled with custard and raspberries that was perfect. My friends ordered some type of cinnamon roll and a cream puff. Everything was beautifully crafted and well balanced. We arrived near the end of the day, so lots of their breads were sold out, so make sure you arrive earlier in the day for the best selection.

La Gourmandine will get you laid. If she's never been there, take her. She will be amazed w your city knowledge and terrible French pronunciations. You're so cultured.

Incredible pastries and everything else. When I say incredible, I mean 'knock your socks off good.' If they have turkey sandwiches when you're there, get one... The bread is kinda tough but that's how I like it.

Go here, you will be converted and want to come back.

Le Gourmandine is your Pittsburgh destination for buttery, delicious French pastries as well as some of the best bread you can get your hands on.  If you hate to wait, show up early, as the line has been known to snake out of the front door and around the block, but trust me, it's worth it.

I have visited on multiple occasions and tried nearly everything, but a few standouts: the basic croissant is airy and flaky, but the brioche is out of this world.  With a few options to try, you can find the brioche that fits your fancy: filled with cream or dripping in sticky syrup and covered in almond slivers are the two that I love most.  Their baguettes are also fantastic.  A crunchy exterior with a tender crumb is excellent for a sandwich or for sopping up extra sauce.  They don't last long, however, so make sure to eat the whole thing the same day you buy it.. Which isn't very hard.

If you're in need of a larger format sweet, their tarts are unparalleled, with crispy crusts, silky custards, and the freshest fruit you could ask for.  I would consume all my fruits on top of their tarts if I could..

Finally, a real bakery. I have been trying to find good croissants in Pittsburgh and La Gourmandie did not disappoint. I had a ham and cheese croissant that was nice and buttery. Definitely going back to try the pastries, which look phenomenal. I only wish there was a place to sit and enjoy, although if it is a nice day, it's a good spot to walk around. Coffee wasn't great, so maybe go to Espresso A Mano for a nice cappuccino first.

I have to be honest. I JUST don't get the hype. First off, a patisserie should have an espresso machine (not coffee that you would find in your office break room). In addition, they should offer (and maybe they do?) tea. Coke and croissant? I don't think so... The quiche was runny and I'm now worried about salmonella and the croissant aux amandes was very heavy. My friend felt that his pain au chocolat needed more pain and less beurre. However, my roommate, who has studied in both France and West Africa, really enjoyed her pain aux raisin.

Hands down one of the best parts of Pittsburgh. This is the first stop when I show anyone around the city. Brie tarts have never disappointed. 

Ambiance: very quaint little store front that gets crowded very quickly. If the line is out the door, they like/expect to keep the door closed and have the line continue to form outside so always dress accordingly. No indoor seating, but has a few outdoor seats if you're lucky enough to grab one during the summer. Fortunately, Lawrenceville is a great place to walk around especially on Butler Street. It's also across the street from a park with plenty of benches and swing sets. Not a place where they love to recommend things, they like to keep the line moving so decide what you want before you get up to order. One of everything is never a bad call. 

Food: The Brie Tart is hands down one of my favorite items in all of pittsburgh. Extremely unique with a fluffy Pasteur wrapped around slices of Brie and onion. Pain au Chocolat, Croissant aux Amandes, and all other pastries are delicious, I try something new every time depending on what I am in the mood for. Bacon Baguette is one of my favorite breads, it is exactly what it sounds like, you really cant go wrong. 

Convenience: Hours can be odd but always easy to swing by on the weekends.

What a delightful find!! My only regret is not stopping here sooner. On a Saturday morning, I waited in line nearly 30 minutes to get inside. It was worth the wait! The staff was helpful. Looking at all of the delicious breads and pastries it was hard to decide what to select! Such visually appealing foods! My husband and son loved everything I bought. Can't wait to come back and try different selections and also try their sandwiches / soups.

Some of these reviews are fairly wordy, so I'll keep this simple:

La Gourmandine is a small shop in a nice area--there's a table outside and a table or two inside. The coffee is hot, the bread is unbelievable, and the quiche is to die for. I suggest the salmon quiche, but all of the flavors are always excellent.

The people behind the counter are friendly and combine everything with affordable prices, and you have a returning customer out of me.

Any foodie in Pittsburgh looking for a nice morning pastry should definitely go here.

As soon as you open the door you could be stepping into a pâtisserie in France. The smells knocks you out - so delicious. I've been in a couple of times - picking up fresh croissants - perfect, flakey and buttery goodness. The tarts are outstanding - citron especially and the sandwiches are outstanding as well. A top hit in town with a seriously helpful and friendly staff.

I. Love. La Gourmandine!

It has to be a special treat for me to make my way within their business hours... but I've found plenty of reasons to celebrate with special treats from there! Birthdays, wedding, friends visiting from out of town, Tuesdays.... you get the picture! 

Call ahead for the raspberry tart, I learned it was seasonal - but it is the most amazing thing I've had, maybe ever. Other favorites include the lemon tart (YASS!) and nearly anything made of chocolate. 

The shop is small and offers little seating so I've mostly boxed my goodies up and taken them home (or to parties) to enjoy. They have been good for days after parties (I've had to force myself to make them last longer, but a piece a day for a week... what a great week!)

great chef, excellent pastries. i have almond allergies and can't try all of their food but everything i had was excellent. their sandwiches are amazing and a great price. i do not go as often but anytime i am in the area i stop by

Amazing! I've been to France 4 times, I've lived in NYC and Philly and love french desserts. This place is top notch. Incredible flavor, presentation, and consistency. The employees are friendly and well trained. Lines out the door are well worth it here.
Delicious! Amazing! The pastries are unbelievable, surprisingly great coffee too. Only complaint is that they are not open on Sunday.

Oh my. This place is GREAT.

My mother and I recently went out for a day of sweets and treats, and this was our top stop.  We also went to Prantls in Shadyside and it did not even compare.  

I had at least 5 different kinds of tarts and pastries and they were all delicious.  The raspberry tart was excellent, and they also made this snowman looking thing.  It comes in chocolate and vanilla, and the vanilla  one was absolutely amazing.  

There was literally not a single pastry in that place that I wouldnt eat.  I plan on going back next week for more treats.  Also the work staff was very pleasant.

Did it feel like Paris? Yes. Did it smell like Paris? Yes. Did I never want to leave? Yes.

Sadly...I had to. 

I was in awe with the beautiful abundance of baked goods along with a wide selection of pastries I have never seen before! I bought way too much for my drive back to DC. Macarons, Croissants, sandwiches, etc. All perfect! 

Tucked away on Butler street, this pastry shop shines above the rest and ensures quality over quantity!

This is a frequent stop for lunch for me. The wait staff is always super friendly and the food is always spot on. I have tried a number of their lunches and I always treat my something to a yummy french tart and I have never been disappointed. I particularly like their tuna fish sandwich which is served on a crispy french baguette and is the perfect blend of tuna and fresh vegetables - sweet onion, celery, cucumber. It is served with lettuce and tomato. It leaves me filling full but not bloated.

For a special treat, call ahead for their Fraisier cake. It is one of the most amazing deserts I have ever tried.

If someone brings you a dessert from this place, they LOVE you. That is the lesson I learned this past weekend. Long story made short - someone who was definitely interested in the birthday girl brought a cake from this bakery to her party and every person at the party could not stop talking about how special this bakery is and gave raving reviews of the dessert before they even tasted it....I then tasted it and learned why these party goers reacted they way they did. Hands down, the most decadent chocolate cake I have ever experienced.

La Gourmandine is part bakery, part patisserie, and they do a very good job at both. They stay within limits; no extravagant, overstuffed breads or pastries. Just the basics, plus a few things here and there. Everything that I've tried here (two visits) is simple, fresh, and delicious. Sandwiches are terrific and a great value. Decor is minimalist and there's almost no seating, but you can eat in the park across the street. Strongly recommended.

I have been looking forward to going to La Gourmandine for the past month. When I tried going there the first time, I got there five minutes after they closed and I was devastated so you can imagine my excitement when I finally walked into the store.

I have seen, been, and tasted my fair share of French pastries because I frequent NYC often and I can say that La Gourmandine can be comparable to any famous NYC French bakery. The time I chose to go there resulted in a long line which allowed me to decide what I wanted since I wanted to get everything. In the end, I picked the abricotine while my friend got the pain au chocolat ou chocolatine. As I am writing this review, I'm actually salivating for abricotine. It was the perfect combination of flaky croissant, pastry cream, and dollop of apricot jam. I also got the chance to try the chocolate filled croissant and also loved it. The chocolate inside was soft which allowed it to seep into the nooks and crannies of the croissant dough. 

One suggestion I would like to make to the owners is to move the chairs and tables from inside the store to outside. When I was waiting in line, the tables and chairs were a hindrance and by moving them outside, people would have a place to sit, eat their pastries, and enjoy the outside weather.

This is the place in Pittsburgh for French pastries and can beat many of the French pastry shops I've gone in NYC. I do not doubt that anything they make delicious!

Bright and cozy french bakery with a wide array of delicious eats. This was my first visit to the actual bakery, whereas I usually get the treats when my husband brings something home. This time we opted for the Mini Eclairs au Chocolat (Choux dough filled with cocoa chocolate custard and topped with chocolate fondant) and the Choux a la Crème (Choux dough cut in half and filled with homemade vanilla whipped cream). The was a bit surprised by the size of Choux a la Creme, but oh it was so heavenly! It's a generous dessert size treat (you could probably split it via twisting it like an Oreo). The filling has a nice creamy mouth feel, with the slightest hint of vanilla. The choux dough was nice and crisp several hours after picking it up. The flecks of the vanilla bean were easily seen, which was a nice surprise.

The bakery is bright and clean, with a few tables to enjoy your sweet or savory selections at (quiche, sandwiches etc.)
One of the best bakeries in the 'burgh, or anywhere for that matter.  Everything is superb and the staff excellent.

Amazing pastries! Breads to die for!
As soon as you walk in the smell transports you to a pattiserie in Paris!
Service is alright... They are really busy, so there's not a lot of time for them to interact or take that extra time.... 
The lack of coffee drinks like lattes or cappuccinos is a downer....

I still love La Gourmandine, but I feel that the overall quality and consistency of their bread is not as great as it used to be.  The pastries are all still pretty delicious, for the most part.  As for the bread, I'm not sure if it's just because I've now been spoiled by better baguettes (see: Five Points Artisan Bakeshop) and other amazing bread (see: Bread & Salt) or if the quality has actually declined.  I still occasionally get baguettes and sandwiches here because they're conveniently located in my neighborhood, but they just don't move me like it feels like they once did.

The service is very friendly and competent; I love all the folks who work here.  It's great that they have seasonal pastries, too.  Always a fun treat!  Get here early on Saturday and Sunday mornings, as the line sometimes goes out the door by 9am or so!

Loved their almond croissant! It's so much more than just a croissant... there's sweet breading on top as well. There wasn't as much selection (perhaps because I came on a Saturday around noon?) but on  smells amazing in La Gourmandine. I saw them regularly bring out new pastries and desserts as well!
This is an amazing bakery. The baguettes alone are to die for, not to mention all the other delicious goodies for sale. This place is truly top notch and as good as any bakery anywhere.

The heavenly aroma that hits when you walk in the door is the first sign of a good bakery. The second is the colorful and gorgeously disayed pastries. I had such a hard time deciding that I went with what I found fascinating based on the reviews here - the Marquise. Although photos show a long chocolate bar, they modified it to a cute, round mini cake. And it was delicious, wow. The outside was slightly "harder" than the buttery chocolate mousse inside, although it was soft enough to fork through easily. The creme brulee custard had the perfect tinge of vanilla. Since I didnt really read the description online, the crispy caramel on the bottom and the yellow cake inside took me by pleasant surprise. All in all, I enjoyed the experience very much. Unfortunately I took so long to eat it that it became cloying, but it tasted wonderful for the first half!

I also ordered a Choquette that was a hollow piece of dough and sprinkled with rock sugar pieces. It was good dough, but nothing fancy, though only 39 cents!

Despite the location being a hassle to travel to, I will be back!

Did they change ownership?  I recently had the almond croissant and the almond filling felt...heavy handed.  

I need answers.  Tell me.  Tell me, now.

When I think of the French, I think of this incredible, long-lost band...

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EuoMIQ8FgKo&feature=related

...and an excellent, socialized health care system and people filling the streets when employers screw with them in any way. 

Methinks they won't be playing any Sortilege in La Gourmandine. Or Gojira for that matter...

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jPXV4vUDlqs&feature=fvst

Enough with the plugging of my heavy musical tastes. I just wanted to show people that I'm not one of those idiots who bag on or stereotype the French.

In a way, I was guilty of that also since I assumed that their food would be a little overpriced and that La Gourmandine would be yet another example of gentrification in Lawrenceville. I.E. "We want the neighborhood people out!"

In actuality, La Gourmandine fits in as nicely as Cigna's once did, and they even have some pretty wallet-friendly lunch and breakfast deals. Have a look...

http://lagourmandinebakery.food.officelive.com/Formule.aspx

Blue-collar me showed up to get a pre-shift bite and found a busy storefront with an eclectic clientele, including a baby walking on the floor and an elderly lady who was just eating up all the attention she was getting from the two on-the-ball young women behind the counter. 

She eh, "couldn't figure out what she wanted" yet made small talk the entire time.  You know the type, and so did the girls, who gave me knowing smirks and glances. 

Me? I needed to be out of there fast, so I ordered a Le Pêcheur and a French Brest...to go. Name the David Lee Roth video I just referenced and win a plastic Green Lantern ring from me. I'll getcha when I getcha.

Le Pêcheur is the kind of long, skinny grinder you can't get at Subway. A baguette houses their good but slightly dry tuna salad that includes tomato slices, onion, cucumber, and lemon. 

People make it seem as if everything French is dainty, but man, this was one tough sandwich. Is baguette supposed to be like this? Usually, when I've had this type of bread, it was softer. LG's bread, on the other hand, was like a Sahs Side pretzel, man. I was fightin' this zep, wrestlin' it to the ground in order to finish it. That's not to say I didn't like it; it was capably appetizing, but I do honestly prefer a sandwich that is somewhat easier to chew as well as a wetter tuna salad. Nothing about this sandwich was a deal breaker though, and I wouldn't mind having it again. 

Now, you know I snagged myself a dessert. 

Have you ever seen the film "Young Sherlock Holmes?"  Remember when Watson was hallucinating after being drugged and thought that all of those exquisite French pastries were attacking him? 

I checked the back of my neck for a blowdart. 

Go rent it if you haven't seen it. Terrific movie. 

Anyway, I gawked and drooled at their dessert case like it was a burlesque show. La Gourmandine really makes their confections into art, so much so that you want to study your treat for a minute before chowing down. I had a bit of trouble deciding, almost playing it safe with a chocolate eclair, until I saw their French Brest, the whoopie pie of French pastries. 

Meanwhile, back at work, a conversation occurs...

"What kinda sammich is that, man?"

"I forget the name of it." 

"Dat looks good. Where'd ju get it?" 

Walking around a warehouse dock with a fancy French dessert will make the goonies curious, especially when you're making guttural noises and swaying like Stevie Wonder. 

Of course our resident Teabagger had to make a smart remark under his breath.

"Boycott them until they call themselves Freedom Bakery." 

"Boycott THIS you %^$#@," I bellowed, fist clenched, a lone middle digit standing at attention.

So well-engineered it was that the chocolate mocha (?) cream (they have vanilla too) didn't shoot out from the sides as the choux was just right in terms of pliability. It also served as an example of how a dessert doesn't have to be richly sweet to be a palate-pleaser. 

Showdown On Butler Street

The wind blows a page of The City Paper across the black asphalt road. It is quiet. Cemetery quiet. Midnight quiet. 

La Gourmandine and Dozen Bakery stand facing each other grasping pistols. La Gourmandine wears a brown hat with white trim, Dozen wears a light blue hat with a darker blue trim. 

They turn their backs to each other and are to take their 12 paces, but Dozen, being dastardly, turns and fires after 6...merely grazing La Gourmandine, barely leaving a mark. Dozen then feels a chill in the back of the neck and turns to run, never hearing the bullet that ended this duel and filled another grave. 

Meet La Gourmandine, the new Sheriff of Lawrenceville.

My wife and I came to La Gourmandine this morning after years of saying we'd go on a weekend morning. Yes, there was a long line.

I've had excellent things from them, including an outstanding cake for my birthday earlier this year that my dad picked up for us.

Today, we tried a wide variety of treats, from pain au chocolat, an abricotine, an feuilleté aux pommes and 2-3 other pastries that looked good. Considering the excellent reputation, we thought they were just "okay."

Personally, I thought the pain au chocolat tasted like it was made last night. It was good, but Five Points has a much better version - simply because it always seems to taste fresh. Same for the abricotine - tasy, but not outstanding.

While La Gourmandine has a wonderful variety, good service, and I'll probably give it another shot, I'd say I give better marks to Five Points for the croissants and pain au chocolate.

Hopefully, we just visited on an off day.

I am so disappointed. We just left. We got assorted pastries and macarons. They were absolutely beautifully looking, but were significantly lacking in flavor. 

We visited another French bakery in Squirrel Hill a couple days ago and were craving more. Their macarons and chocolate croissants were life changing. We've been wanting more, but it's difficult to get to. We saw the good reviews on yelp and thought we'd give this place a try since we were passing by. 

The macarons lacked flavor to the point of it being hard to distinguish what flavor each was. 

The pastries seemed to either be over or under baked. None were just right. Some tasted eggy and had a rawish center while others left an unpleasant burnt taste in our mouths. 

Next time we want French pastries, we will make the drive to squirrel hill instead.

Stopped by to get some treats for Mother's Day.  Everything was excellent.  From the Frasier, macaron au fruit, to the almond croissant and even the pain de pie for sandwiches.  Tried the focaccia garnie that was scrumptious. Never disappointed in our selections.  If you come on a Saturday or Sunday morning there is usually a line but it doesn't take to long.  Surprised they don't have two cash registers on some of those days to move the line faster.

I rarely give 5 star for a place I've only tried once, but this one definitely takes the cake. And the cookies. And the pastries. And pretty much everything else possible. UNFFFF is all I have to say. My mom, BF, and I decided to visit here after already being semi in the neighborhood. The girl behind the counter was friendly and answered all of our retard questions. (I fail at anything remotely French language related...except food...and even then, I fail pretty hard.) 

We got a pistachio....hoagie-looking-thing (which was amazing btw, had essence of coconut to it), a lemon tart which was OUT of this world sour and amazing....and we also tried a chocolate dome shaped thing. Everything we got was fantastic. My mom also bought a plain croissant and a chocolate croissant for my sister. I tried a bite of the plain one and it blew my mind.

Seriously....the local French bakery in St. Louis ain't got nothin' on this place. The baker is clearly highly skilled and the ingredients they use here are very clearly TOP NOTCH. As someone who is an avid bakery and appreciator of fine French desserts, I can tell this place is money. Quality speaks volumes when it comes to baking! (Followed by science and practice, of course!)
delicious and unique.  Worth a stop for anyone looking for a special treat or to try some authentic french desserts.
Perfect spot to grab a quick lunch and go. The bread is amazing. The quiche was buttery, eggy and light. Simply spectacular.

I usually go to the Lawrenceville location but I was out in Mt Lebanon and wanted a quick breakfast with my son. The location is really cute. It's very similar to the other location, but had parking. The food was exactly the same. My almost 2-year old scarfed down almost a whole order of chocquettes and I had an almond croissant with a cup of tea. There were a few more tables than Lawrenceville, I think, and we were happy to be able to grab one and enjoy our breakfast. It's nice that there are two locations to visit with the same quality at each.

If I could eat here everyday I would. I love the pain au chocolate for breakfast, the Parisian baguette for lunch and macarons or the marquis for dessert. My 16 month old loves the choquettes! The staff is always so friendly and the atmosphere reminds me so much of Paris. I can't recommend this place enough!

Mmmmm. La Gourmandine. 

The yelp reviews did it justice. Lots of little baguettes and pastries filled this place. 

Our selection was a little sad- I mean, what do you expect for stopping in at 3pm on the Saturday of Labor Day weekend? But we split this chocolate eclair dessert- and mmmmmm. Oh how I love desserts. Nice and chocolate-y, yet not overally sweet? Mmmmmm.

Had we had been more hungry and had we come earlier, we totally would have gotten more. Definitely worth the stop..... :)

Disclaimer: We only had a savory treat - and absolutely plan to visit again for something sweet. Everything sure looks to die for...

I stopped in to the shop for a hangover breakfast of sorts. I had a simple le Parisien (French baguette with butter, ham, and Swiss cheese) - and it hit the spot! The baguette was among the best I've ever had; and, the ham, cheese, and butter were perfectly proportioned - fresh, tasty combo of great flavors. I can't wait to go back and sample some pastries!

Pass this shop on my way home quite often so I have been wanting to try this place for a while! They do close pretty early so I was finally able to make it last week. La gourmadine did not disappoint. Their croissant was so flaky and buttery. The almond croissant did not look like a croissant but wow did it taste amazing. Every bite had flaky buttery almond goodness. The only thing I wasn't too impressed with was the spinach and goat cheese quiche. It was mediocre nothing special. The last thing I tried was the cream puff which was amazing. The cream was perfect not too thick or sweet and the pastry was perfect. Thank god I only bought one, I could have eaten four in one sitting. 

Overall, a wonderful bakery in the south hills. Will definitely make an effort to return for their decadent pastries!

I gained like 5 lbs in 2 weeks stopping here everyday on the way to school last semester and it was worth it. Everything is so fresh, often you see them continually restocking the case right in front of you just-made items. The gourmandines are my favorite. It's like a chocolate croissant with custard and they're heavenly. If there's a line, it goes quick and it's worth it so just wait! I wish they were open right now (and delivered)

We found out about this bakery thru Yelp.  We had been wanting to try out those almond croissants for quite some time.  We happened to be in the area on an early Saturday afternoon.  Unfortunately for us, they were out!  No croissants of any kind!   We opted for an apple pastry and a pistachio eclair.  Both were delicious.  Can't wait to visit, again.

Incredible French bakery in Lawrenceville - from the bagettes to macaroons to pastries and breads....delicious! Special cakes are also often available. The bakery sells sandwiches, soup and coffee too! You.won't.be.disappointed.

If you have been to France you are wrecked for all pastries and bread forever. If you haven't then go to La Gourmandine and you can have a similar experience! It's where we go to get our fix. It's all awesome. Just go.

Time to update! This place is just amazing! We have gone more than a few times now and it gets better and better hence going from a 4 star to a 5 star rating. If you are ever anywhere near (& by near I mean within a 50 mile radius) you must stop. It is a very tiny place but it doesn't have to be big. This little place packs a punch. The eclairs are just, wow! Never had any better...the chocolate is just so wonderful. I can't even describe it. It is just phenomenal! The pastries are light and fluffy and full of amazing flavor and tasty goodness. I would say right behind the eclairs is the chocolate fondue cake.. talk about the most moist chocolate cake we have ever had, wow! We haven't ever had anything bad and staff is always friendly and helpful. Again, I would recommend this place to anyone and everyone who would or will listen!

La Gourmandine offers by far the best, most luscious cake that you can buy in Pittsburgh and the surrounding areas.

One of my friends gets these for all her parties and their wonders make me ecstatic every time.

Runners Up

According to both my own pastry-loving tastes and the inherited wisdom of my life-long Pittsburgher mother and aunts, the runners-up options for "best cake in Pittsburgh" are both more "old-fashioned and sugary" than La Gourmadine: Prantl's Burnt Almond Torte or the strawberry-layer cake from The Oakmont Bakery.

The best in the city, and if my 5-year-old had a vote, we'd be here everyday. I go here for coffee and macarons, or lunch because their sandwiches are great, simple meals. Try the pistachio éclair or the lemon tart.

So happy to have found a little piece of France in Pittsburgh! As a francophile and food-lover, i was excited to try this place out. It exceeded my expectations. The little shop mirrored the boulangeries in France. I ate the sandwich La Campagnard, which was a simple turkey sandwich on a baguette. Its simplicity, freshness, and texture made for an amazing gastronomic experience. I also sampled the Pistachio macaron which was reasonably priced and very good as well. Of course, i had to get a Baguette Tradition, which had an intoxicating smell and had the perfect consistency of crunchy and fluffy on the inside. 
Will definitely go back soon, and i suggest anyone who is visiting Pittsburgh must go here. 
The only downside was that there were only a couple of tables, and with the line forming into the street, not everyone could sit. Luckily, there is a park across the street.

MMM.  I can't say enough good things about La Gourmandine.  I love everything I've ever had from them 
quiche
almond croissant 
ham and cheese with bechamel croissant. 
and a dozen or so desserts.
Every single one - delicious

I ummmm, might have a hard time finding the words to express how much I love the pastries I tried at this place.  

It's just a little 3 table bakery counter place, so don't go thinking you will linger for hours over your espresso cup.

The coffee is self-serve and quite decent.

Didn't try the bread. 

Now, it's all about the croissants.  Bought a chocolate for there and a pear tart to go.  I took one bit of the chocolate and immediately went back to the counter for an almond croissant.  Not because I didn't like the chocolate, but because I looooooved it and wanted moooooore.  Now, if love is what I felt for the chocolate croissant, the almond one, well the closest word might be l'amour.  French love.  Much stronger, more powerful.  I could only eat half.  The other half went home and was downed with the pear tart a few hours later.  As in, could not wait for the next day.

The place was so good I texted a picture of the almond croissant to a French friend in DC and promised her I would bring one the next time I am in town. She took one look at the pic and replied, "Real deal."

My goodness, for a French pastry lover, I sure chose the wrong side of town to live on. Murrysville/Monroeville area only has 1 bakery and that's Moio's. No macarons for anyone! 15 miles and 45 minutes later with a car-full of hangry people, we arrived at this joint to devour all the breakfast pastries. 

The website talks about a lunch deal and there is no such thing. I also called asking about reservations and you know, maybe the lady could have helpfully told me there is no seating area at all. But nope, I go in expecting to order a lunch and eat it there but there's standing room only. I still made the most of the trip by ordering an assortment of pastries though. Here's my review of that:
-very fresh
-authentic assortment (no doughnuts allowed here!)
-taste was good

I tend to judge French bakeries based on their execution of the ubiquitous pain au chocolat. The appearance was puffy and magnificent. The taste was not bad--most of the pastry was air, but I did like that it was not as sweet as Panera's version. The smell though and the smell of the bakery itself was definitely lacking. I believe I had the pleasure of smelling most bakeries in Paris and they would completely astound passersby. The smell was so strong it was almost visceral, like imagining melting butter and flaky pastries...
The best thing here was the almond croissant thingies and why the heck did I only buy one? The cream puff was also amazeballs but next time I will skip the apricot tart and the coconut bread cupcake thing. Next time, bakery, we will meet again and I will treat this as a whole day trip.

I've been here a few times and I really like it. The almond croissants are fantastic. I haven't had the opportunity to try out their lunch options yet but I've heard from others that it's also great. Service has always been good. I love that they're open on Mondays, because most bakeries aren't. Parking is tough. The last time I've been there weren't any spots open and we had to park in the lot for the insurance office next door.

Paris! What can I say? I was thrilled that this French inspired bakery opened a second location in Mt Lebanon. They have their own parking but the lot is very small and of course filled. Across the street is an abandoned gas station where I would imagine you can park if need be.

Stopped here for lunch with my daughter. I ordered the goat cheese and spinach quiche while she settled for a ham and cheese on a French baguette. They advised me for dessert to get the almond danish which is filled with almond creme. It must have been very popular since I got the last one! I noticed later on they restocked them.

That sandwich of her's was so huge I thought there was no way she could finish it but she did. My quiche was heated and brought out to me. It was okay. I'm not used to goat cheese but it wasn't overly filling so I could enjoy my danish. That almond danish was very flaky and literally came apart on me as I ate it. It was delicious!  She had some sort of chocolate bar dessert which she let me sample. It was very rich and quite filling had I ordered it.

They only have a few tables if you wish to eat in. Take out is available and of course you can call if you want to preorder baked goods or their breads. 

The staff was very friendly and helpful. If you eat inside then your food is served on actual dishes and they will let you box up leftovers to take home. As we were leaving I purchased a fruit filled macaroon cookie for my daughter and a chocolate chip style danish for a friend. I was told that danishes will only last a day but does not need refrigeration while anything in their refrigerated case should be placed in the refrigerator once you get home.

This place is easy to miss since it sits near the corner of Cochran and Cedar roads. Still it made for a nice mid day treat for both of us. My advice would be to get there early for best selection. Will definitely visit it again sometime in the future.

While checking out the area for an upcoming event I stumbled upon the first location of La Gourmandine. I had no trouble parking and was pleasantly surprised to find it open on a Sunday morning.

I went in and like its sister shop over in Mt Lebanon, the layout is virtually the same. They are noted for their flaky almond pastries which I have had before. That alone is my number one recommendation! However, since I have had it twice I decided to try something different. So I asked the lady about some of the new items they had. One was called Clafoutis which is made out of bread pudding and stuffed with cherries. The other was lime Bavarian cream with raspberry. I ordered both since they told me I could store the Clafoutis in my refrigerator for one day.

They served my lime Bavarian cream on an actual plate with a fork. They also have a few tables where you can sit and eat. Again, they offer sandwiches as well as coffee or tea. You can also order cakes or pastries in advance. The staff was very helpful and explained everything to me.

That new lime Bavarian cream was delicious and not overly filling which was perfect for me!  I plan on eating the Clafoutis later but I'm sure since they recommended it to me, I know I won't be disappointed. When I had finished eating my dessert I placed it to the left of the cash register which I was told was fine so they could take it away.

This place is easy to miss while you are driving down Butler St but again the place fills up very quickly since it is a popular place for sandwiches and French pastries.

I did ask if they were planning to add any other locations at the moment and was told they aren't. Either way if you visit this location or the one in Mt. Lebanon you will get exceptional service and some of the best Parisian desserts you can imagine.

Review number 136 of this quaint little bakery is going to be short and sweet (no pun intended) and to the point. I loved the place. Like a little piece of Paris right on Butler Street. 

The pastry looked amazing but I wasn't there for the buttery, flakey croissants, the eclairs, or other delectable treats. I wanted a loaf of crusty, airy spelt flour bread. I wasn't disappointed. Besides all the treats you'd be served at a French cafe, they also serve up some pretty mellow and smooth coffee. My only beef, just like any business on Butler Street, the parking is ridiculous.

Decadence defined here. La Gourmandine has mastered the art of baking perfection!  

Every.  Single.  Item.  Is.  Amazing.

This place is a MUST-TRY when in Pittsburgh.  

The only caveat is you could literally eat everything here... and come back for seconds.  And if you do, well, that would be most definitely bust your diet.  And probably your belt!

La Gourmandine, if only you were located in Nashville...

This place is one of those rare establishments where you can 'just go there and get what looks good', and it will be good.  Once when my brother was visiting town, and we showed up later in the day because of that (all the pretty and flashy stuff sells earlier, as it should, because it's all really good), what was left was not visually too impressive...  looked like bread, other types of bread, and some different bread.  However, I ended up selecting some bread-looking thing with marzipan filling, and my brother got some other bread-looking thing with a different twist, and both were really great.  I hate to use the word 'amazing', but here it fits.  I said, "Wow" out loud when I tried it.  Then I stared at it to try to remember what it looked like, and hoped it would remain a secret so that there would always be one or two when I came late.

I've had a variety of items from this bakery, and have never been disappointed.  I have been surprised, and always in a positive way - how many places or things can you say that about?  It's just a great bakery.  I highly recommend this place.

I live dangerously close to La Gourmadine, and I'll admit it takes quite a bit of self-control to reserve this as an occasional treat. It's a tiny little place, but the number of items offered never ceases to surprise me. They have a huge variety of breads, pastries, and some savory items like sandwiches and quiche. On a weekend morning you can expect a line, but it moves quickly and you'll be outside enjoying your treats in no time at all.

Two of my favorite items:

The macarons aux framboises is essentially two giant macarons with fresh raspberries and a lychee cream in the center. The macarons are perfect, with that deliciously chewy outer shell and soft inside. The cream and strawberries make a wonderful combination, and overall it's a really refreshing treat. 

The marquise is an elongated bar covered in flawless chocolate and beautifully decorated with gold leaf and some other embellishments. Inside are layers of chocolate mousse, creme brulee, and a crispy caramel crust. The flavor combination is spot-on; it's not overly rich or heavy, but just right.

If you're in the area, I definitely recommend stopping in. You will not be disappointed!

Didn't make it around the menu yet but from the taste of the two pastries I had they deserve every star available.  Choux la creme and pear tart, unbelievable pastry. Quality is very similar to Tartine in San Francisco (minus the cakes) and I'll add to this review once I try the quiche and sandwiches.  Once you've eaten around enough in your life you get an idea that this is one of those, "You can't go wrong with anything you order."

La Gourmandine deserves the 5 star reviews.  It's a spot-on French bakery.  I've been here a few times now, and last week I stopped in for a sandwich.  It's just like I got in Paris...a small loaf of crusty, chewy bread, meat, cheese, mayo, lettuce.  Sounds simple right?  It is, and that's what makes it so awesome.  

The inner fat in me wants one of everything in that sexy glass display case (at once) but I'm attempting to pace myself.  So far I've had the lemon tart, and last time I had this flaky, donut-like pistachio creme thing.  Holy crap, I'm pretty sure it's made by magical leprechauns.  You would expect it to be overly sweet, but it's this perfectly-balanced delicous little crack-stick.  

When I was getting ready to leave, they brought out a new cake that was covered in large chocolate shavings.  Even if that damn thing is $50, I'm buying it for my next party.  A lot of their goods in the display case looks like art.  Edible, delicious, art.

The best bakery in Pittsburgh. I dream about this place. Vanilla Religiouse is one of the best pastry items I've ever tasted, but it hasn't been on the menu for quite some time. 

Must haves:
Almond Croissant
Baguettes 
Lemon tart
Chocolate Eclair
Brie or pizza tart
(You can't go wrong with any item actually).

Not much seating. La Prima coffee, but it's usually warm not hot. But who cares? You go here for the baked goods.

I've never had something that wasn't delicious from here, only different levels of deliciousness. My favorite is their La Gourmandise pastry filled with vanilla cream and chocolate chips. Their almond croissant and quiches are also amazing. Prices are very reasonable, around $2-3 for a pastry which is well worth the quality that you get. The staff is super friendly and very patient while you take your time choosing from all the goodies. Definitely recommend checking this place out!

Hands down my favorite bakery in Pittsburgh. Because of this place, I start to look for French bakeries in many different cities. No where else is like La gourmandine. Every time I go home to visit my family, I always buy a bunch of their goodies to treat my family. They enjoy every single pastry I brought back. My personal favorite is their chocolate pastries, especially Marquis and chocolate eclair. Another one I really love is the lemon tart. Mmm also, their breads are so delicious too. I tried their sour dough, their French bread, and the croissants. Their Almond croissant is to die for btw. I also tried multiple large cakes, such as the chocolate moose cake, and the pistachio cake. They both are without a doubt delicious. I got so many things here and never once disappoint me. 
Now I think about it, I really like one of their mini puffy bread thingy. I don't remember the name, but there is sugar on top. They are very cute and make a good snack to share with friends. Anyway, if you haven't been here, please change that ;)

My newest addiction! I'm embarrassed that it has taken me this long to get to La Gourmandine, but now that I've tried it, I am hooked. Just the fact that I'm writing this review as I am chowing down on a chocolate croissant should be enough proof. The shop itself is small and options are more limited than other bakeries, but I'm tellin' ya, you won't be disappointed in anything you decide to go with. Since it was my first visit, I decided to test the waters and get a little of everything since they all looked so darn pretty. This was probably a fantastic and dangerous idea because they were all incredible. Highly recommend the almond croissant which was my favorite! They're about $3-5 per item so it is a bit pricier but honestly, it's worth it, even for the biggest penny pincher like myself. There was a bit of a wait, but the line moves fast and the staff are so friendly and helpful (especially when you're uncultured and can't pronounce all the French names like me). This is a must-try for anyone with a sweet tooth!

Living within walking distance is dangerous. Seriously it's so hard to stop myself once inside. Of course the French bread is to die for and the croissants are always flaky, light and pleasing. If I could, I'd eat the pastries for every meal!

I have been to this bakery multiple times and each time I am impressed with the selection as well as the service. 

I arrived here about 15 minutes before opening on a Saturday and a line had already formed out the door.  

What we sampled: 
Pain au chocolat ou Chocolatine (outrageously delicious and flakey)
Brioche fine (sampled later in the day and was still as good as the things we tried for breakfast)
Croissant aux amandes (delicious almond croissant!)
Baguette traditionnelle (best baguette ever!)

I will definitely return, and even with the line once the doors opened I was out in about 3.5 minutes!

The croissants are delicious. They remind me of being in Paris. They also have an item that looks like a candy bar and is the most delicious thing ever. It's messy to eat with a creamy, nutty middle. Its good! Be prepared for a 20 minute wait if you go around lunch time.
Some seriously high-quality desserts and baked goods here, but they go fast--I'd arrive early in the day, because if you come later on, there won't be much available.

This place. I can't even... It is just incredible. AND now a second location!!! The best french pastries I've ever had. Wait. The best pastries I've ever had! And the most artful too!

Walking in you're met with the most amazing smell you've ever experienced in your life. Then you gaze across the display of beautiful creations, you almost don't wait to eat them. But you do. And you enjoy them, immensely. There really isn't a pasty I've had that I didn't like. The almond croissants are my fave's, but I also enjoy their pistachio desserts and chocolate wafer-like desserts. Forgive me for not remembering their proper name. I think I was too busy shoving them in my mouth.

This location is a lot bigger than their orginal one, plus the free parking lot is a major perk compared to the Lawrenceville street parking. Plus, there's free wifi! I think it would be dangerous to sit here for a while...

As a smart man once said: "Once it hits your lips it tastes so good!"

That sums up everything about La Gourmandine Bakery!  The delicacies in the case looked scrumptious, it's hard to choose one... so I choose two!  I bought the Délice de Pistache and Paris-Brest.  The Délice de Pistache is Choux dough covered with pistachio mousseline and topped with dark chocolate.  I had planned on only taking a bite.  That did not happen.  In fact, as soon as I took the first bite I was floating away towards the pearly gates of heaven!  It was just divine!  The Choux dough was light and almond tasting, the pistachio mousseline was fluffy and distinctly tasted of pistachio (I hate when fillings don't taste like what they should) and the chocolate just topped off my dessert decent!  

The Paris-Brest is Choux dough filled with hazelnut cream.  It actually looks almost like a doughnut.  It was the same heavenly taste!  They're actually very similar but different shapes.  The hazlenut again was distinct and the Choux dough was light with a slight crisp to it.  I would say my fave had to be the Délice de Pistache though.  But both were fantasmic!

I also grabbd a sandwich, which was very good as well... But I didn't want to mention that first because I was too excited about th desserts!  I had the Le Campagnard, which is a French baguette with mayonnaise, turkey, lettuce, tomatoes, and Swiss cheese.  The baguette was incredible, and I don't normally even like them.  Too hard to chew.  Even though it was a baguette, you could tell it was freshly baked that day, so it didn't have that stale taste a baguette from say, Panera, would have.  I'm glad they offer lunch, because it's a chance to grab a quick sammich and bring home dessert for later... or stuff your face with it then!

Fancy?
Location'l another downtown area in Pitts?? I am not sure...
The shop is nice looking from outside and when I got there people were already in line for their fancy bakeries. 
And it is indeed good!
